Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2011 11:29PM marjie wrote: Chiming in as a fellow Canadian although not stage IV - so I hope you don't mind!!  I went through the exact same treatment regime as you are receiving.  After my surger I had FEC (x3) Docetaxol (x3) Herceptin (x18) plus 33 rads (25 regular + 8 Boosts).  Right now I have 4 more Herceptin to go and then I am "done". I agree with Coolbreeze - you defnitely need to make some noise for your pathology report...it states all the details of your cancer and I found it to be such a valuable piece of information.  I was constantly pulling it out and looking up different things.  Your cancer is staged and graded on your pathology report - my surgeon gave me mine and went through it with me. Best thoughts going out to you moving forward....

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 11:46AM marjie wrote: lyndalynda - regarding the fruits and sugars, I am a wellness nutritionist and used to council people on weight loss and eating healthier.  That was always a pitfall - when you tell people they should aim for 8 servings of fruits and veggies, often you get the veggie-haters eating 8 fruits in a day.  Just remember that sugar is sugar and your body will convert it and store it as fat if you have too much - even coming from fruit.  I always tell people 2 fruits and 6 veggies is a good split. I definitely understand the frustration though when you think it's a good thing and you're told it's not.  I always told my clients not to deny themselves certain foods but remember the three steps "balance, variety, moderation" with MODERATION being the biggest point (IMHO).  I know that these days I really struggle with "proper" eating and I am very short on my proteins lately.  Nobody is perfect.  I found and excellent book in the library at the cancer centre that I think I will purchase: Eating Well Through Cancer, Easy Recipes and Recommendations During & After Treatment by Holly Clegg and Gerald Miletello, MD. Good luck and don't get discouraged!  This is a hard road for all of us sometimes.

Posts.Content: Aug 9, 2012 12:50PM marjie wrote: I had a hard time with chemo...always in and out of the hospital because of my blood counts.  I remember right near the end of my chemo, I had to visit the ER due to fever.  I ended up staying the night in a triage bed.  In the morning, a woman came in to the bed next to me (we were separated by curtains), the guy on the other side was her husband....I have no idea why he was there, but he said to his wife "oh my God, I gotta get out of here - this place is full of freaks - there's a guy over there who tried to commit suicide, and some old dude had a heart attack, and the lady right in the next bed has CANCER!!" It took me a minute to realize he was referring to ME! Did he think cancer made me deaf??  It was just hurtful I guess - something that stuck with me.  Perhaps I should have said something, I don't know - wouldn't have accomplished anything except to likely upset me more and I really wasn't up for it.

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2012 09:34AM - edited Mar 2, 2012 09:36AM by marjie Caitlin - I am a 9/9 as well.  Very aggressive.  Sounds like you have the right attitude - nobody can pick your treatment for you, but I will say that once you are done, you need to be able to say that you have done absolutely everything you could.  My onc's parting words - "go live your life now, you've done all you can so don't dwell on whether or not it will come back, the odds are in your favour" My cardiologist says that I have some heart damage but it is all manageable with medication which I do not require and maybe never will.  I'm very active and I'm not symptomatic at all.  People can live for years managing heart failure, not so much with cancer. Edited to add:  I'm in Canada so our regime is a little different, but the medications are all similar.  I am ER/PR- and Her2+ as well.  I did FEC-D chemo x 6, Herceptin x 18 + rads.

Eileen, I know this is hard - it will grow back!! Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2011 10:30AM marjie wrote: When I was very sick, very bald, and in the hospital - one night, I couldn't sleep and a nurse peeked her head in at me then came in when she saw I was awake.  I remember her saying "look at you, you're just a baby..." (I was 47!), and then she leaned close and said "I'm not really supposed to get into this with the patients, but I want you to know that it will be ok...I was right where you are now, 3 years ago and here I am now, with my hair and my life back..." Then she left and came back with a little cup of icecream for me which I finished off and then went to sleep. LOL it was like a dream...I felt like I was 5 yrs old, but I think of her oftern and am thankful that she told me that.

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2012 07:51AM marjie wrote: The beginning is the worst - the waiting, the decisions, the shock of it all.  It's a GIGANTIC learning curve!  But once you have a plan, things move will move quickly and you'll find that your focus will change because you are taking action. I'm one of the classic cases who walked into the surgeons office and demanded "just take them both off...".  My surgeon was excellent - you could tell by her face that she had definitely heard this before.  She talked me down off my ledge and went about explaining all my options, outcomes, etc., and in the end I had a lumpectomy.   My tumour was 4cm and any bigger would have taken my choice away, but after looking at the MRI, my BS felt she could get it all.  That was our deal...if she didn't get clean margins at the first surgery, then I wanted it off.  LOL we shook on it! Since the MRI also showed clear nodes (I still had a SNB), it was a good option and in her opinion, since I was heading into chemo, rads & Herceptin, she said it was in my best interest to go into the treatment as strong as possible, so why over-do the surgery if I didn't have to.  In the end, the choice was mine and I really feel comfortable with it, although there are those who think I made a mistake and it will be my demise. Anyway - you have found a good place, and lots of help and support. We will all help you through. ((hugs))

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 01:01PM marjie wrote: I cut my hair to a shorter style before I started treatment.  Once it started coming out, my scalp was really uncomfortable and it was messy...coming out in clumps.  We buzzed it off at the lowest setting ( no guard ) then the next day it was still uncomfortable so my DH (don't laugh ladies) took some of the stubble off with duct tape and then we used an electric razer to take it all off.  For me it was more of a comfort thing...my scalp felt sore and itchy until I got rid of the hair.  It's now starting to grow back in and it's very soft and ummm....well fluffy, I guess!
Posts.Title: when losing hair... ninastar Letlet

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2012 09:03PM marjie wrote: I loved my port - same here though - I had a year of Herceptin on top of chemo.  That being said, chemo fried my veins almost immediately and I was also hospitalized on IV quite often, so the port was a life saver for iv's, transfusions, blood draws as well as chemo. It was sore going in, but coming out was nothing and I have a slight line and a dent where it was  but it's not overly noticeable.  I was able to bathe, swim, and maintain all activities which would not have been possible with a picc line - not to mention the risk of infection.
Posts.Title: Port or no port??? Camillia lago

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2010 01:14PM marjie wrote: I had my snb at the same time as my lumpectomy so I can't judge on the time-off requirements.  I was told to expect to be off work once I had my surgery for 6mths up to a year but that is factoring in the chemo and rads that are my next step. I had to have the injections for the snb the day before surgery.  For me there were three shots (no dye) and to be honest they were quite painful, but they were quick about it.  They had me in a machine for 20 minutes and then were able to mark my sentinal node location for surgery.  I had two nodes removed along with my tumour.  Luckily, my surgeon was able to do it all with one incision which looks to be about 3-4" inches long. So far so good, I wasn't really given specific exercises or anything but I am making sure I have range of motion in my arm - but no lifting or excessive movements.  The most discomfort I have had with this surgery was the shots the night before...your procedure may be different, they could have you frozen or under anaesthesia at that point. No worries, big hugs....it will be just fine and over before you know it.

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2012 03:09PM marjie wrote: It's my understanding that if you have a lumpectomy rather than a mastectomy, they prefer to radiate the remaining breast and especially the "tumour bed" to avoid cancer growing back in the same area (it only takes one rogue cell!). It also depends on the size of your tumour as well as the pathology of the cancer.  For me, even if I chose to have a mastectomy, because the cancer was an aggressive grade 3 and Her2+++, they wanted to do rads. It really wasn't bad. MUCH easier than chemo, and I guess for me, at least I know that I have done all that I can.

Posts.Content: May 25, 2012 09:42AM marjie wrote: I was the same - 10 days of shots. It's easier if you let it warm slightly and inject it slowly - when it's cold and injected fast it can sting an awful lot!  I had the strongest bone pain at the beginning but Tylenol took the edge off and warm baths helped too.  I usually did my injections in the evening so I could just take a bath and head to bed.  Some ladies have posted that taking a Claritin prior to the injection really helped but my onc did not recommend it. I just noticed this is the stage iv forum - my apologies - but hopefully a little advice that may help. ((hugs))
